Description: Mammalian scientific names correspond to PHYLACINE v1.2.1 (Faurby et al. 2018) and the IUCN Redlist Version 2016-3 (2016). Avian taxonomy was based on most recent peer-reviewed literature. Post-domestic species are named with their post-domestic subspecies epithet (Groves and Grubb 2011 John Hopkins University Press). E.g. post-domestic donkeys are Equus_africanus_asinus, while their pre-domestic ancestors are Equus_africanus.
Species common name

Global species status. "Extant", "Extinct before 1500 CE", "Extinct after 1500 CE", "Extinct after 1500 CE, but wild in introduced range", or "Extinct before 1500 CE, but wild in introduced range". Introduction status from Lundgren et al. 2020 PNAS.
Levels / Range: "Extant", "Extinct before 1500 CE", "Extinct after 1500 CE", "Extinct before 1500 CE, but wild in introduced range", "Extinct before 1500 CE, but wild in introduced range"

Description: Binary variable indicating if a species was domesticated and is now wild (1) or was never domesticated (0). Domestic species differ from non-domestic species in some trait values, particularly body mass.
Taxonomic class corresponding to the IUCN Redlist Version 2016-3 (2016).
Mammalian taxonomic order corresponding to PHYLACINE v1.2.1 (Faurby et al. 2018) and the IUCN Redlist Version 2016-3 (2016). Avian taxonomy was based on most recent peer-reviewed literature.
Mammalian taxonomic family corresponding to to PHYLACINE v1.2.1 (Faurby et al. 2018) and the IUCN Redlist Version 2016-3 (2016). Avian taxonomy was based on most recent peer-reviewed literature.
Body mass in grams.
Method used in cited literature to determine body mass. See Table 2.
Ordinal ranking of best available evidence quality, with direct observed evidence ranking highest (3), and expert opinions and taxonomic inference ranking lowest (0) (see Table 2).
Notes on body mass designation.
Body mass reference.

Importance of graminoids (i.e. grasses, excluding bamboo and herbaceous forbs) in diet. In general, 0 indicates that graminoids constitute 0-10% of diet; 1 indicates 11-20%; 2 indicates 21-50%; and 3 indicates 51-100%.
Importance of browse (including bamboo and herbaceous forbs) in diet. In general, 0 indicates that browse constitutes 0-10% of diet; 1 indicates 11-20%; 2 indicates 21-50%; and 3 indicates 51-100%.
Importance of meat (vertebrate and invertebrate) in diet. In general, 0 indicates that meat constitutes 0-10% of diet; 1 indicates 11-20%; 2 indicates 21-50%; and 3 indicates 51-100%.

Dietary guild when excluding meat consumption to focus on herbivore effects on vegetation. One of either "Browser" (Diet.Graminoids = 0-1 & Diet.Browse.Fruit = 3), "Mixed Feeder" (Diet.Graminoids = 2-3 & Diet.Browse.Fruit = 2-3), or "Grazer" (Diet.Graminoids = 3 & Diet.Browse.Fruit = 0-1).
Dietary guild including meat consumption. Species with ³2 for meat consumption are scored as omnivores. One of either "Browser", "Mixed Feeder", "Grazer", "Omnivore".
Method used in cited literature to determine diet. See Table 2.

Ordinal ranking of best available evidence quality, with direct observed evidence ranking highest (3), and expert opinions and taxonomic inference ranking lowest (0) (see Table 2). In cases where high quality data contradicted each other strongly we reduced ranking by 1. Likewise, if data values were inferred from a congeneric or confamilial species (in the case of diet and habitat use) we also reduced ranking by 1.
Natural history notes and justification for diet designation and description of ambiguities.
Diet references.

Inferred herbivore fermentation type. At times, for completely extinct lineages, we classified hindgut caecum and colon based on body size and similarity to modern species Ð which is justified in Fermentation.Type.Notes column. One of either "Simple Gut", "Hindgut Caecum", "Hindgut Colon", "Foregut Non-ruminant", and "Foregut Ruminant".
Levels / Range: "Simple Gut", "Hindgut Caecum", "Hindgut Colon", "Foregut Non-ruminant", and "Foregut Ruminant".

Description: Fermentation type ranked by fermentation efficiency following Hume (2002 Acta Zoologica Sinica) with Simple Gut = 0, Hindgut Colon and Caecum = 1, Foregut non-ruminant = 2, and Ruminant = 3.
Method used to assign fermentation type.
Ordinal ranking of best available evidence quality, with direct observed evidence ranking highest (3), and expert opinions and taxonomic inference ranking lowest (0) (see Table 2).
Notes and justification for fermentation designation and description of ambiguities.
Fermentation type references.
Limb morphology as categorical variable, consisting of "Plantigrade" or walking on soles of feet; "Digitigrade" or walking on toes of feet; and "Unguligrade" or walking on hoof.
Method used to assign limb morphology. Primarily inferred within Family, or observed directly from morphological or observational evidence.
Ordinal ranking of best available evidence quality, with direct observed evidence ranking highest (3), and expert opinions and taxonomic inference ranking lowest (0) (see Table 2).
Notes and justification for limb morphology designation.
Limb morphology references.
Non-exclusive binary variable indicating use of aquatic habitats. 1 indicates significant use of aquatic habitat, 0 indicates non-significant use.

Non-exclusive binary variable indicating use of terrestrial habitat. 1 indicates significant use of terrestrial habitat, 0 indicates non-significant use (in this case only for completely arboreal primate species).
Non-exclusive binary variable indicating use of arboreal habitats. 1 indicates significant use of arboreal habitat, 0 indicates non-significant use.

Habitat as a categorical variable, consisting of "Semi.Aquatic" (1 for Habitat.Aquatic and 1 for Habitat.Terrestrial), "Terrestrial" (1 for Habitat.Terrestrial and 0 for any other), "Semi.Arboreal" (1 for Habitat.Terrestrial and 1 for Habitat.Arboreal), or "Arboreal" (0 for Habitat.Terrestrial and 1 for Habitat.Arboreal).
Method used to assign habitat use.
Ordinal ranking of best available evidence quality, with direct observed evidence ranking highest (3), and expert opinions and taxonomic inference ranking lowest (0) (see Table 2).
Natural history notes and justification for habitat designation.
Habitat references.

Column: *Note that special characters (e.g. accent marks, umlauts, Greek and latin characters, isotope symbols) have been removed from all text and from References to prevent character corruption with import and export into softwares such as R.
